Because the laser was mounted at a 90* angle it corrected for the 90*-out-of-phase application of the collective and thus appeared in phase with the control inputs, correct?

The swash plate is so cool. The helicopter seems like it moves how the swash plate moves. The swash plate tilts the perpendicular blades the same way as the swash plate tilt. If the swash plate tilts front of helicopter side up, then when the blades are perpendicular to the front of the helicopter, they will also be tilting front of helicopter side up. Applying lift to the front side of the helicopter. The gyroscopic precession is engineered into the swash plate and it makes controlling the helicopter tilt so simple and awesome. Way simpler on the pilot!

The cyclic pitch control input and the laser beam orientation are in phase because the pointer is mechanically pointed 90 deg. ahead of the blade. This implies the blade pitch is changed 90 deg. in advance. This is not necessitated entirely by gyroscopic effect, but due to blade flapping.
This is exactly how NASA fakes the earths curvature.

Awesome visual representation.

I think I can explain why the light arcs during collective input. Put simply, it is because of the fact that the room is rectangular. The corners are farther away from the axis of rotation (spinning blades) and the light can travel farther before it hits the wall. This allows the light to be the highest at the corners and lowest between the corners.

To understand this on a deeper level, try visualizing the light beam on a 2D platform at any given point in time (meaning freeze time). When you have no collective input, the light beam is completely horizontal (no y component) and you get a straight line all the way through the rotation. When you add collective input, the light beam is pointing up or down from the rotational plane (the horizontal/straight line from earlier) with an angle θ. Now, the rotational plane and light beam create a right triangle with the wall.

The rotational plane is the x component, how high the beam is up or down the wall is the y component, and the light beam itself is the magnitude (hypotenuse of right triangle). As the light beam maintains its angle (θ) with the rotational plane, the distance of the x component (how far the blades are from the wall) affects the y component (how high the light goes up the wall). Say, a large distance (x) would mean a bigger height (y). That is why the light beam is higher (or lower) in the corners compared to the middle of the wall.

The reason why it is hyperbolic is because if we were able to see the physical light beams itself during collective input (would've been made possible with a fog machine), then the beams would've created a single cone. The wall is your plane that is cutting into your cone, which is why the line you see on the wall is a hyperbola (half of it at least). If we had two lasers (one of them opposing the laser in this video), then the second laser would make a second cone opposite to the first cone. The end result would be a double-mapped cone and a full hyperbola. This took me a while to figure out.

I don't have any drawings to help you visualize what I'm trying to say, sorry. If you read this far, may I say you are a wonderful and patient human being.

Conclusion(s): If you did this demonstration in a cylindrical room, then the line should remain straight during any collective input. The wall is the plane that is cutting into the cone the light beam creates when there is collective input into the helicopter which is the reason why the line is hyperbolic.

Though this is old, I still hope to hear if I've got this right. Probably won't, but whatever.

So, I don't have any mathematical proof of this, but cyclic input changes the pitch of the laser as it revolves around the rotor shaft (cyclically; go figure) resulting in a straight line being projected onto the plane of the wall (i.e. I imagine you'd see a curved line if you had a curved wall).

The collective input changes the pitch, but the pitch does not fluctuate as it revolves. This means that if you could see the entire trace of the laser, it would be a cone. The wall intersects this cone parallel to the axis of the cone, giving you a hyperbola, as it is not parallel to any side of the cone.

the shwashbuckle plate or however you say it (SPELLING IS HAAAAARRRD) is the thing that is controlling the pitch, so when the pitch is making the helicopter go to the side, the lazer is flat due to the fact that the swashbuckle plate is pointing forwards to backwards. When the pitch is making the helicopter go forwards or backwards, and the swashbuckle plate is pointing from side to side, the line is curved because of the way that the swashbuckle plate is turning the blades (lazer) on a disk. We are getting a curve as the wall is a straight one. if we put the same setup in a cylindrical room with the rotors center aligning with the axis of the cylinder we will get a straight line. This is because as the laser points down or up from the rotating plane the distance travelled by the laser on the opposite straight wall is diff at different points and this shifts the laser down or up and if it is a cylinder no matter in which direction the laser travels the same distance so no shift.

...will be parallel to a tangent plane of the cone, and you could in theory get a parabola. It’d just result in a circle being traced on the roof, or require that the helicopter be rotated and jammed into the wall. I think?

Hyperbolic... sort of. In that, only half a cone is formed by the rotating laser, as it only shines out of the one end. That half-cone, intersecting with a plane (the room wall) will have a locus of points that defines a single, continuous curve. However, if the bottom half of the cone were present, and the room walls extended far enough downward, there’d be a second intersection with that same plane, causing a hyperbola. But only up to a point; turn the collective up enough, and the room wall..

Hyperbola because the light emitted by the laser creates a cone pointing up or down depending on the pitch. If a cone is oriented in the same way as the the path of the laser is in (where the base is parallel with the floor) a Parabola is defined as a cross section parallel to the pitch of the blades and a hyperbola is defined as a cross section at a plane normal or perpendicular to the base of the cone. Because the wall is normal to the floor and independent of the pitch the arc is a hyperbola.

science never sucks. It always pushes. So your theory of  a helicopter being a big "sucker" does not make sense.

A helicopter is essentially a big "Sucker". It works by providing lift by sucking air through the rotors.  What happens when you suck air into your mouth?  Now what happens if you hold your mouth 5mm away from a piece of glass and suck?

The glass is the ceiling and the heli is your mouth.

Oh, just correcting something I stated: Assuming a clockwise rotation, You would increase the pitch on the Eastern side, which causes the rotor disk to tilt up at the back, and _decrease_ the pitch on the west, causing the rotor disk to tilt down at the front.

If I get your meaning, you need to go back to some of his first videos, and get the magic of cyclic. The cyclic constantly adjust the pitch of the blades as it goes around. When the blade is on the west, the cyclic increases it's pitch (tilt, 'bite'); as the blade moves around to the north, the cyclic decreases to neutral, and continues to decrease it's pitch to negative as it moves to the east. As the blade continues to move around, the cyclic steadily increases it's pitch to maximum again.

The little ones you can buy in the mall counter rotate the two sets of rotors which neutralizes the gyro effect one blade creates making it easier for newbies like me to have fun with.  To turn those, they speed up or slow down one set of rotors to increase/decrease the gyro effect one set has on the other.  The tail rotor is mounted on the same plane as the main rotors and only controls forward/aft motion.  

The big chinooks are just made of magic.

Yes it is.  Check this video out.  The guy actually uses positive collective pitch to make his rotor blades stop in mid flight, so the heli is in free fall.  He then uses negative collective pitch and the upward wind through the rotor disc to restart the blades and give enough momentum to the blades to land the heli, all without power! Auto rotations are another subject, but so much fun to do when you pull it off! (Not so much when you dont and crash!

Hmmm, I guess the blades are never stationary, even when the engine dies.

Forward momentum causes the blades to spin? OK, this is a little difficult to visualise. Just checked out a couple of videos. Pro's use this method and land safely every time.
Robert - I meant "fall like a rock" in the same fashion as calling f16's lawn darts. :-)

When the engine dies, the helicopter becomes a gyrocopter. The forward momentum of the craft will cause the blades to spin. It spins enough so that the helicopter will glide, and the rotational can be used, similar to the manner that wmwnwmn suggests to stop the craft and land normally-ish on the ground.
The craft never 'falls like a rock', however. There should be a number of videos that make things clear, and Destin will probably create one before he finishess with helicopters.
Yeap, that's what I was thinking. Thanks! Not a maneuver for the novice, I take it! A demo of this would be awesome @destinws2 :)

As the helicopter falls like a rock, the pilot will use the air he is falling through to increase rotor speed as fast as possible.  Right before smashing into the ground he'll pull up on the collective to momentarily create lift, and hopefully the helicopter will slow it's decent fast enough to land safely.  This is called autorotation.

comment_by: Gmail Does Not Know My Name
comment_text:
Idea: fill the lower sections of the room with something that will glow under the influence of the laser, such as smoke or an aerosol, and (if needed) get a more powerful laser, then film from above.
This way, instead of just seeing where plane of the rotors intersects with the wall you see the plane itself, and you can see when it's significantly conical due to pitch.
It'd also just look awesome. :p

IF, and ONLY IF, anyone wants
some stimulating yet relaxing music
accompanied by amazing photography;
Check my Channel. Doubt you'll regret it.
Thanks all, keep on enjoying the good stuff.
You captured exactly what I was feeling: "This is so awesome I wanna cry."

Destin, I still don't think I quite understand all the mechanics behind helicopters but I definitely understand them BETTER than I ever did before.  Especially with gyroscopic procession.  I somehow managed to graduate college and never learn that.  And I got a degree in a computer related "hard-science" field.  I'm no English major.  This series of videos was amazingly informative.  I don't know how you don't have millions of subscribers.  THANK YOU!
A cone intersects a plane in a parabola. Notive the cyclic pitch is not curved because the pitch angle is zero. Its simply a tilting plane, not a cone. Math is awesome.

It might be hard, but could you please use maybe a red laser for the other blade of the helicopter. This way we could see how they work together better, not just have to imagine it.

Thats some where between a 3 to 5 mW laser, Not nearly powerful enough to do any damage in the 1/100th of a second it would be in your eye. That doesn't mean you should try it just means your relatively safe. Kind of like how people put on safety glasses when they mix baking soda and vinegar, its not going to explode but they want to promote safety. Safety - The act of combating natural selection.

This is the most brilliant method of showing how a helicopter works I have ever seen. But its poorly implemented. You needed to explain which way the rotor was spinning, if the laser was point 90 ahead or 90 behind (VERY IMPORTANT!). In this case the laser was pointing ahead, so it was showing what the helicopter would actually do. Possibly confusing people as you previously said that it happens 90 degrees before, which was still occurring, but it was showing 90 ahead.
Should've got the smoke machine out. :P
